title: Understanding Colposcopy
subtitle: What it is, why it's done, and what to expect

content.value: A colposcopy is a simple procedure to look for abnormal cells on the cervix or vagina.

items.text: Feels similar to a smear test

content.title: Remember
content.description: A colposcopy helps identify changes early so they can be monitored or treated to prevent cancer. It's a preventive measure that can protect your health.

sections.cardTitle: Why You Might Need a Colposcopy

items.text: Cervix looks unusual during an examination
Follow-up of previous cervical cell changes

content.value: After a colposcopy, mild spotting and cramps are normal. Seek medical advice if you have:

items: Heavy bleeding (soaking a pad every hour)
Feeling unwell or symptoms getting worse

content.value: Most people recover without problems, but it’s always best to get checked if you’re concerned.

steps: Positioning — You'll lie on an examination table, just like during a smear test
Speculum Insertion — A speculum is gently inserted to hold the vagina open
Solution Application — A vinegar-like solution is applied to highlight abnormal cells
Examination — The colposcope examines your cervix closely from outside your body. Sometimes the vagina or vulva may also be checked if needed.

content.title: Good to Know
content.description: The colposcope stays outside your body — it does not go inside the vagina. Think of it like a special microscope that gives your doctor a better view.

content.value: If your doctor sees anything unusual, they may take a small tissue sample (biopsy) immediately during your colposcopy.

content.text: What to expect during a biopsy

items.title: Mild discomfort
items.description: May cause a brief pinch or cramp

items.title: Lab analysis
items.description: The sample is sent to a laboratory to check for abnormal or precancerous cell changes

content.text: Why might I need a biopsy

content.value: A biopsy helps confirm whether abnormal, precancerous, or cancerous cells are present. It's the most accurate way to determine exactly what type of cells your doctor is seeing and plan the best treatment if needed.
If no abnormal cells are found:
If abnormal cells are found, treatment options include:

items.title: Cone Biopsy
items.content: Removes a cone-shaped piece of tissue from the cervix to remove abnormal cells and allow detailed laboratory testing

items.title: LEEP (Loop Electrosurgical Excision Procedure)
items.content: Removes abnormal cells using a heated wire loop. Quick and effective outpatient procedure.

content.title: Key Point
content.description: Key Point Treating abnormal cervical cells early greatly reduces the risk of cervical cancer developing. These treatments are very effective, and follow-up checks help make sure the cells have been successfully treated.

items.title: Mild spotting for a few days

items.text: Take paracetamol or ibuprofen for discomfort (if safe for you)
Avoid using tampons until any bleeding or discharge has stopped
Avoid vaginal sex until bleeding or discharge has stopped
Use sanitary pads instead of tampons if needed

content.value: Call your GP, colposcopy clinic, or NHS 111 if you have:

items: Heavy bleeding (soaking a pad every hour) or bleeding that is getting worse
Severe or worsening abdominal pain not relieved by painkillers

content.value: These may be signs of infection or complications, which are uncommon.
